collection: Vale, Mr. E - private,26 Thorley Park Road, Bishop's Startford, Herts.,Landowner: Mr. Tinney, Matching Halls Farm,Site Rel. NBI/Or. 1
site: Essex,Matching,Matching Hall Farm,Found July 1987 in ploughing; the field previous pasture, had been ploughed for the first time in 'years'; sword found caught up in cultivation, but finder was satisfied that it was turned up in a particular part of field which showed a blackened rectangular surface discoloration - c. 25 x 25 yds.
surface: Mostly pale yellow - green dry surface; odd few pits to light green - probably damage rather than pocking, etc.; small areas dark brown smoother out - poss. relif patina.
description: Dimensions: EL (straightened) 613; W ht. 24.2; Wsh. 58.5; Max B fg. 9.0; max T bl. 8.8; W ws. 31.7; max W. bl. 50.2,Typology: v. slight bowed fg. cross-section; 'slot' depressions around rivet holes; ricasso more-or-less flattened; hint of e. bev. below ricasso rapidly disappears; rounded loz. bl. section tending to lenticular towards tip; rivet holes markedly hour-glass,Manufacture: remains of thin cg. fl. within hilt slot; some likely porosity apparent on surface.,Condition: hilt terminal broken off in antiquity; remainder broken in two - fracture gold, [..[ recent, prob. due to find circumstances; whole length very twisted & contorted - prob. ancient, as are most of edge dents and 'tear' low on bl. c.; small gouging just below shoulders gold - recent; also odd gold flecks along edges & small even in one ricasso; very tip blunted - anc. (+ modern).,Attached Material: scattered orange staining - apparently on surface - possibly adhering dust.
remarks: PIF (O); DF (S); SI; CI; SN 9 Oct. 78; Sb. A.; Mr. Vale, 8 Aug. 78

site: England,Cambridgeshire,Chippenham,Badlingham Road 1,"The site...was upon the open field to the right of the road leading from the village street to Badlingham, and at about 85 yards from it and the fence separating the field from the strip of meadowland which intervenes between it and the brook. At this point which is just below the brow of the rising ground, some men digging for gravel in the middle of last December (c. 1883-6), unearthed the relic at a depth of about two and a half feet from the surface. It lay with its point directed to the North West and its hilt at a lower level, upon, and partly within, a stratum of picked flint stones of larger size than the average of these found in the surrounding soil, which is of sandy nature and unprofitable for sifting..."(full extract in documents file) (a)

patina: Dark, peaty [orcassing?] in patches; considerable areas golden bronze. Traces of blue & violet colour on grip and pommel.
